title: Architect Ricardo Álvarez-Díaz is All About Sustainability and Resiliency
text:
Ricardo Álvarez-Díaz is the co-founder and CEO of Álvarez-Díaz & Villalón, an architecture and interior design firm based in San Juan, Puerto Rico, and Coral Gables, Florida.



The firm is dedicated to holistic and sustainable architecture and design. Mr. Álvarez-Díaz, 46, works with his wife, interior designer Cristina Villalón, and their portfolio spans the U.S., Central America, South America and the Middle East.

In 2017, Álvarez-Díaz was appointed by the Governor of Puerto Rico as a member of the board of directors of Invest Puerto Rico, as well as a member of the Governor’s Construction and Housing Advisory Committee. In the same year, he was appointed by the U.S. Secretary of State as a liaison between the private sector and FEMA on critical infrastructure, construction and housing issues.



We caught up with Mr. Álvarez-Díaz to discuss the importance of both connectivity and self-sufficiency, the best luxury spots in the Caribbean, and more.

More: Compass’s ‘Chief Evangelist’ on the Importance of a Home’s Context

Mansion Global: Describe your dream property.

Ricardo Álvarez-Díaz: My wife and I are currently building our own dream house. For us, the location was very important. We care deeply about life in the city. It’s in a walkable area of San Juan. It’s close to where our kids’ school is located. Most important is that it’s fully Net Zero, and not connected to the water system or electric system. Our company has been working hard on issues of sustainability for years. We want to prove to the naysayers that you can do this, and be completely resilient. We’ve seen in the last couple of years, an enormous number of natural disasters.



Being from Puerto Rico, I love the beach. We have a beach home that’s 30 minutes away, and for me it’s the best way to escape.



MG: Do you have a real estate property that got away?

RAD: It got away not because I wasn’t able to buy it, but because I was stupid enough to sell it. We had an apartment in Miami and we sold it a couple of years back. Our kids were getting older and we weren’t taking the family there that much. Looking back on it, we’re a little sad we don’t have it any more.

We have another one now, but that other one was the one that got away.

More: Design Firm Chief Says Luxury is About Tapping Into All the Senses

MG: What does luxury mean to you?

RAD: For me, it’s efficient. comfortable, resilient.

For me, it’s about getting rid of any chains. When you live in a hurricane-prone place, it’s about having the luxury to not depend on anything else and be self-sufficient. It’s a luxury to have electricity and water when no one else has it. A home should be comfortable and make your life less difficult.

MG: What area do you think is the next hub for luxury properties?

RAD: Places like New York and London are always going to be luxury. But the Caribbean—the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico, for example—offers the benefits of investing in U.S. territory, with the rule of law of the U.S. and tax benefits.

In the last couple of years, we’ve seen multimillion-dollar properties spring up in Condado in San Juan.

From Penta: 'Devolved Parliament' Sets a Record for Banksy

MG: What’s the biggest surprise in the luxury real estate market now?

RAD: Two new hubs were a complete surprise to me. Boise, Idaho, and Nashville. A lot of millennials are looking for quality of life. People from Oregon and Washington state were looking for an alternative and went to Boise. The same is true with Nashville. There’s so much development in those places. Those places were a complete surprise to me.

MG: Where are the best luxury homes in the world and why?

RAD: For me, it’s Spain. We have a family home in the North, in Asturias, and the area’s very luxurious and very anonymous. People are very down to earth. I love the walkable city mentality.

MG: What’s your favorite part of your home?

RAD: My library. I can sit, read, relax and come up with sketches and designs.

More: Luxury is About Inner Wellness, Says Los Angeles-Based Designer

MG: What best describes the theme to your home and why?

RAD: We’re currently building it. For us, it’s about simplicity and comfort. We have hectic lives with our kids and our work. We don’t want to make life more difficult. For me, it’s all about simplicity and efficiency.

MG: What’s the most valuable thing in your home?

RAD: I have a growing collection of books. I have a 1787 edition of Vignola’s “The Five Orders of Architecture,” and a 17th-century copy of Don Quixote. When I travel, I like to go to these old antique bookstores.

In a way they’re more valuable than my sketchbooks, which I’d never sell, though I’m not sure anyone would want to buy those anyway.

MG: What’s the most valuable amenity to have in a home right now?

RAD: Connectivity and back-up systems. It’s going to get to a point where people really value resiliency, and without connectivity you can be isolated and lost.

When we talk to our clients, that’s the first thing they ask about.

More: Designer Andre Fu Says a Home Should Reflect Its Neighborhood

MG: What’s your best piece of real estate advice?

RAD: You’ve got to be pragmatic and have an exit strategy. Today’s lifestyle isn’t necessarily going to be next year’s. It’s reckless to assume that one property is for life.

Excess and customization diminishes the long-term value of property.

I’m one of those architects who tends to be very pragmatic.

MG: What’s going on in the news that will have the biggest impact on the luxury real estate market?

RAD: Recessions happen about every seven years, and it has been like that since the Great Depression. We’re several years overdue for a recession now. It’s likely to happen sooner rather than later. In the short term, luxury properties suffer.

MG: What is the best area now for investing in luxury properties?

RAD: There’s a difference between buying property and investing in property. You need to look to places like Phoenix, Arizona as investments.

I always recommend looking at the best tax benefits, weather and amenities when it comes to investing.

Places like Myrtle Beach, in South Carolina, and Condado and Dorado in Puerto Rico are great.

More: Italian Architect Says a Building Should Be ‘Timeless,’ and an Apartment Should be Comfortable

MG: If you had a choice of living in a new development or a prime resale property, which would you choose and why?

RAD: I would prefer a new development. The reason is because of convenience. I have three daughters—12, 10 and 9. I personally look for what a community has to offer—stores, entertainment, proximity to schools.

Because we travel a lot, I like a place that has a lot of amenities. But don’t get me wrong, I love a re-sale that has a historic element-—townhouses in Chicago or New York or Old San Juan.

MG: What area currently has the best resale value?

RAD: If you focus on population increases and tax benefits, you have the best resale.
